div.head: To my worshipfull good friend Maister Robert Dalington.
div.p: BEing well assured that this your worke (out of your owne protection) would in the end present it selfe to the generall view; and likely enough some one that loues you not so much, nor knowes you at all, might haue the passing of it: I haue put my selfe in the way of your reproofe; and am become a theese of this nature, to steale no more from you then I will againe giue to you. If I could perswade you there were a fault in modesty, you would bid me publish the vertue which you tye vp in too straight bonds. My fault is, I haue done that which would haue beene done; and the offer is so full of loue, that it lookes for a punishment accordingly.
